question_text: Explain the physical mechanisms by which wind alters the flame shape and heat flux distribution of window-ejected fire plumes, considering different wind directions (facing, sideward, back-roof), based on the momentum interaction between wind and buoyancy-driven flows described in the provided paper.
standard_answer: Wind alters window-ejected fire plume behavior through momentum interactions with buoyancy-driven flows, significantly affecting flame morphology and heat transfer. The wind-induced momentum competes with and modifies the buoyancy-induced momentum of the fire plume, leading to changes in flame position, shape, and thermal characteristics. For all wind directions, this interaction can push the fire plume closer to the facade, which increases convective heat transfer to the building surface despite potential reductions in flame temperature. The pressure differences induced by wind also modify the neutral plane height at the window and alter air inflow rates, impacting the critical heat release rate required for flame ejection. These mechanisms operate differently depending on wind direction due to varying momentum vectors relative to the window opening, but the fundamental physics involves the competition between externally imposed wind momentum and internally generated buoyancy momentum in the fire plume system.
